part_Text3: in a rosette, persistent, large (12 - 25 cm long, 2 - 7 cm wide), wavy-lobed with numerous short marginal spines and scattered larger ones intermixed, and reddish midveins.
part_Text4: alternate, green beneath, similar in shape to basal leaves but a bit smaller.
part_Text5: few, large, with the involucre about 3.5 - 7 cm wide and more than 3.5 cm tall. Spines on outer series of bracts (phyllaries) 1.5 - 3.5 mm long and erect.
simSp_comments: Cirsium hillii can be distinguished from other pinkish flowered thistles by its large, yet relatively few flowering heads, stems lacking spiny wings, and the leaves being green beneath. Both C. muticum and C. arvense can be confused with C. hillii, but they normally have more than five flowering heads and these less than 3 cm broad, less than 3.5 cm high, and the spines on the phyllaries less than 1 mm long. However, when flowers are not present these three species can often be confused.
habitatEcology: Dry prairies and other open places, often in sandy soil, but rare in the Chicago Region.
notes_comments: The original collection of C. hillii was from a Chicago Region locale, Pine Station (now part of Gary) in Lake County, Indiana. Reverend Ellsworth J. Hill, a common Chicago area collector near the turn of the 19th-20th centuries, collected this plant in 1890 and it was named for him. This specimen, called a type specimen, is deposited in the herbarium at the New York Botanical Garden and is available for viewing on-line. Many current authorities believe this taxon is not a separate species from the eastern C. pumilum, under which it has been placed as either a subspecies or variety, still retaining the epithet hillii. Today, the continued existence of C. hillii is under threat from habitat loss. Fire suppression is also thought to have severely diminished populations of this species since it requires open bare soil for seedlings to develop.
notes_linkText1: View type specimen of C. hillii at the New York Botanical Garden
etymology_comments: Cirsium comes from both the Greek words kirsion, meaning a kind of thistle, and cirsos, meaning "swollen vein" for which thistles were once thought a remedy. Hillii is named after Rev. E. J. Hill (1833 - 1917), a respected botanist who first collected this plant in 1890.
furtherInfo_linkText1: U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service Rangewide Status Assessment
references_citation1: Moore, R. J. and C. Frankton. 1966. An evaluation of the status of Cirsium pumilum and Cirsium hillii. Canadian Journal of Botany. 44:581-595.

growthForm: Perennial herb that flowers once and then dies
part_Text1: a taproot, often 2 m long, penetrating deeply.
part_Text2: only produced when the plant flowers and then branching in the inflorescence. The stem is blue-green, covered with dense, soft, white hairs, and has very few spines.
part_Text3: in a rosette, long-stalked, blue-green, up to 30 cm long (though small in first year), deeply pinnately lobed with central portion and lobes very narrow, with a few obscure teeth along margins, weak soft spines at the tips, and covered with soft white hairs. The basal rosette of leaves may be the only evidence of the plant for several years.
part_Text4: alternate, almost stalkless, very similar to basal leaves though blades decrease in size gradually upwards on the stem.
part_Text5: several per plant, rather large, up to 5 cm broad. Involucre 2.5 - 3 cm tall, and covered with white hairs on outer surface. Outer bracts (phyllaries) tipped with prickles 1 - 2 mm long.  Inner bracts (phyllaries) longer than the outer ones and tapering to a long, slender, somewhat soft bristle.  Heads often remain intact and attached to the stem after flowering.
part_Text6: creamy-white (less commonly pale pink) and very fragrant.
simSp_comments: Cirsium pitcheri is the only cream flowered thistle in the Chicago Region and it is only found on the near dunes surrounding Lake Michigan. In addition to the flower color and singular location of the species, the blue-green cast of the stem and leaves, the soft white hairs covering the plant and the lack of numerous sharp spines on the stems are very diagnostic characters.
habitatEcology: Open sand in the dunes of Lake Michigan, but nonexistent naturally in the Chicago Region except for areas in the dune region of Indiana and Michigan where it occurs sporadically on exposed sand, primarily near blowouts. The species used to occur on beaches and foredunes, but all populations in the Chicago Region in these habitats have been wiped out. The species requires open, loose sands, which are exceedingly more rare in current times due to recreational uses and land development. Efforts to stabilize dunes have put additional pressure on the species because it decreases habitat availability. Additional problems have arisen with influx of invading exotic species, grazing of plants by deer, rabbits and insect larvae, and trampling by humans. The coat of white hairs on the plant is adaptive to the harsh, exposed environment. The silky white covering helps reflect sun rays to keep the plant temperature lower and consequently decrease water loss.
notes_comments: One of a few species that only grow in the Great Lakes region, Cirsium pitcheri occurs on the sand beaches and dunes of Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, and at two localities along Lake Superior. The closest relative of this unique thistle is thought to be C. canescens, which occurs in the sand hills of the Great Plains (Loveless and Hamrick 1988). It is believed that C. pitcheri evolved after the retreat of the Wisconsin ice sheet about 10,000-12,000 years ago (Johnson and Iltis 1963, Loveless and Hamrick 1988, Mickelson et al. 1983). The plant requires from 5 - 8 years of growth to achieve its minimum flowering size. The stem and flowering branches are produced only once since the plant dies after flowering (monocarpic). The flowers are visited by numerous insect pollinators. The seeds are either wind dispersed as individual achenes, or entire heads remain attached and are buried as the parent plant dies and falls over. Seed dispersal is usually clustered within five meters of the parent plant (Keddy and Keddy 1984, Loveless and Hamrick 1988). Due to human impact on the dune environment in our area, this species has suffered great habitat fragmentation, which leads to reproductive isolation. The species was extirpated (extinct) in Illinois in the early 1900’s. In 1991, several groups, including the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service, The Morton Arboretum, and the Chicago Botanic Garden, started work to reintroduce the species in Illinois at the Illinois Beach State Park. Cirsium pitcheri still exists in scattered natural populations throughout the dunes in Indiana (at both the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore and the Indiana Dunes State Park). The plants are monitored and managed in attempts to continue the existence of viable populations in the area. This species is listed as Threatened under the Federal Endangered Species Act.
etymology_comments: Cirsium comes from both the Greek words kirsion, meaning a kind of thistle, and cirsos, meaning "swollen vein" for which thistles were once thought a remedy. Pitcheri is named after Dr. Zina Pitcher who discovered the plant along Lake Superior around 1826-1828.
furtherInfo_linkText1: Plant Profile at Center for Plant Conservation
furtherInfo_linkText2: Profile from Michigan Natural Features Inventory
references_citation1: Johnson, M. F. and H. H. Iltis. 1963. Preliminary reports on the flora of Wisconsin; No. 48: Compositae I. Transactions of the Wisconsin Academy of Science, Arts and Letters. 52: 255-342.
references_citation2: Keddy, C. J. and P. A. Keddy. 1984. Reproductive biology and habitat of Cirsium pitcheri. Michigan Botanist. 23: 57 - 67.
references_citation3: Loveless, M. D. and J. L. Hamrick. 1988. Genetic organization and evolutionary history in two North American species of Cirsium. Evolution. 42(2): 254-265.
references_citation4: McEachern, K., J. A. Magnuson, N. B. Pavlovic, 1989. Preliminary results of a study to monitor Cirsium pitcheri in Great Lakes National Lakeshores. Porter: National Park Service, Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore.
references_citation5: Mickelson, D. M. L. Clayton, D. S. Fullerton and H. W. Borns, Jr. 1983, The late Wisconsin glacial record of the Laurentide ice sheet in the United States. In Late Quaternary environments of the United States: The late Pleistocene, ed. H. E. Wright, Jr. and S. C. Porter, 3 - 37. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press.
references_citation6: Voss, E. G. 1996. Dicots concluded (Pyrolaceae - Compositae). Part 3 of Michigan flora: A guide to the identification and occurrence of the native and naturalized seed-plants of the state. Bloomfield Hills, MI: Cranbrook Institute of Science.

part_Text1: delicate, wiry, erect, yellowish green, and unbranched below the inflorescence.
part_Text2: reduced to tiny, narrow scales, more or less opposite, stalkless, less than 3 mm long.
part_Text3: on short stalks on the main stem or ascending branches, yellowish, small (3 - 4 mm tall), with four sepals, four petals, anthers about 0.5 - 1 mm long, and an almost nonexistent style.
simSp_comments: Bartonia paniculata, which occurs more south and east of the Chicago Region (especially along the Atlantic Coastal Plain), has the leaf scales alternate at least in the middle of the stem, and the anthers are smaller (0.3 - 0.5 mm long).
habitatEcology: Sphagnum bogs and swales, acid and peaty edges of low moist sands, and sometimes moist woods or thickets, but uncommon or even rare overall.
etymology_comments: Bartonia is named after the Philadelphia botanist, Benjamin Smith Barton. Virginica refers to the plant being "of Virginia" in the wide sense, that is from the eastern United States.

part_Text2: opposite, spreading, stalkless, yellow-green, egg-shaped (2 - 5 cm wide, 5 - 15 cm long) with long pointy tips, wide bases, and smooth margins.
part_Text3: (1 - 20) stalkless, yellow-white or green-white, almost closed, and compactly clustered at the top of the stem.
part_Text4: five, connected below, with separate tips having smooth edges and a ridge-like structure (keel) running down the outer face to the connected tube portion.
part_Text5: five but fused with shorter membranes (plaits) between the actual petals.
part_Text7: a two-valved, elliptic capsule with numerous flattened, winged, smooth seeds.
simSp_comments: This is the only whitish-flowered gentian in our area except for the rare albino of other species. Albino forms of Gentiana andrewsii or its varieties have rough-prickly leaf margins, hairy margined sepal tips, and plaits longer than the alternating petals. Albino forms of G. puberulenta may also be similar, but they have a hairy stem, very narrow sepal tips, opened flowers, and separate anthers.
habitatEcology: Moist prairies, sometimes swales or other wet or moist clearings, but uncommon overall.
etymology_comments: Gentiana is named after Gentius, king of Illyria, who supposedly discovered a medicinal value for the yellow gentian. Alba is the Latin word for white, which refers to the whitish flowers.
references_citation1: Pringle, J. S. 1967. Taxonomy of Gentiana, section Pneumonanthae, in eastern North America. Brittonia. 19:1-32.

part_Text2: opposite, stalkless, somewhat lance-shaped (3 - 15 cm long, up to 4 cm wide), with somewhat long pointed tips, and rough or prickly-hairy margins.
part_Text3: (1 - 25) stalkless, bluish violet to pinkish violet, closed, club-shaped, and clustered at the top of the stem and often in the axils of the upper leaves.
part_Text4: five, connected below, with separate, hairy-edged tips that are much shorter than the connected tube portion.
part_Text5: five but joined to longer, toothed or jagged-edged whitish membranes (plaits) between the actual petals.
part_Text7: a two-valved, elliptic capsule with numerous flattened, winged, smooth seeds.
simSp_comments: Gentiana andrewsii is represented by two varieties in the Chicago Region. See links below for further information. There are two other species of closed gentians in our area that may be confused with G. andrewsii. Gentiana alba differs by having whitish flowers and completely smooth leaf margins and sepal tips. Gentiana saponaria has much narrower leaves (under 2 cm wide) with shorter, not long pointed tips, and the free part of the sepals are almost as long as the connected tube portion.
habitatEcology: Occasional in damp prairies, wet meadows, and other moist open ground.
notes_comments: The only observed pollinators for this gentian are bumblebees, which appear to be the only insects strong enough and smart enough to open the closed flowers (Costelloe 1988).
etymology_comments: Gentiana is named after Gentius, king of Illyria, who supposedly discovered a medicinal value for the yellow gentian. Andrewsii is named after the English botanical artist Henry C. Andrews.
references_citation1: Costelloe, B. H. 1988. Pollination ecology of Gentiana andrewsii. Ohio Journal of Science 88:132-138.
references_citation2: Pringle, J. S. 1967. Taxonomy of Gentiana, section Pneumonanthae, in eastern North America. Brittonia. 19:1-32.

part_Text2: opposite, stalkless, somewhat lance-shaped (3 - 15 cm long, up to 4 cm wide), with somewhat long pointed tips, and rough or prickly-hairy margins.
part_Text3: (1 - 25) stalkless, bluish violet to pinkish violet, closed, club-shaped, and clustered at the top of the stem and often in the axils of the upper leaves.
part_Text4: five, connected below, with separate, hairy-edged tips that are much shorter than the connected tube portion.
part_Text5: five but joined to longer, toothed or jagged-edged whitish membranes (plaits) between the actual petals.
part_Text7: a two-valved, elliptic capsule with numerous flattened, winged, smooth seeds.
simSp_comments: There are two other species of closed gentians in our area that may be confused with Gentiana andrewsii var. andrewsii. Gentiana alba differs by having whitish flowers and completely smooth leaf margins and sepal tips. Gentiana saponaria has much narrower leaves (under 2 cm wide) with shorter, not long pointed tips, and the free part of the sepals are almost as long as the connected tube portion. In addition to this variety of G. andrewsii, the more western variety, G. andrewsii var. dakotica, has been found here though it is extremely rare. The western variety can be distinguished by its better-developed petal tips, which are triangular to rounded and often have a free, pointed tip up to 3 mm long.
habitatEcology: Occasional in damp prairies, wet meadows, and other moist open ground.
notes_comments: The only observed pollinators for this gentian are bumblebees, which appear to be the only insects strong enough and smart enough to open the closed flowers (Costelloe 1988).
etymology_comments: Gentiana is named after Gentius, king of Illyria, who supposedly discovered a medicinal value for the yellow gentian. Andrewsii is named after the English botanical artist Henry C. Andrews.
references_citation1: Costelloe, B. H. 1988. Pollination ecology of Gentiana andrewsii. Ohio Journal of Science 88:132-138.
references_citation2: Pringle, J. S. 1967. Taxonomy of Gentiana, section Pneumonanthae, in eastern North America. Brittonia. 19:1-32.
references_citation3: Voight, J. W. and R. H. Mohlenbrock. 1985. Prairie plants of Illinois. Springfield: Illinois Department of Conservation, Division of Forest Resources and Natural Heritage.

part_Text1: normally unbranched, usually hairless, but sometimes with short, swollen-based hairs.
part_Text2: opposite, stalkless, dark green, less than 2 cm wide, and short hairy on the margins. The leaf shape is variable, ranging from linear to elliptic, but usually widest near the middle, possibly blunt-tipped, but never long pointy.
part_Text3: stalkless, blue (sometimes violet), open to loosely closed, and in clusters of one to eight at the top of the stem, but also at the end of branches at the upper part of the stem in larger individuals.  Each flower is subtended by a pair of bracts, which are longer than wide.
part_Text4: five but fused at least half their length into a hairless, 5 - 15 mm long tube.  Sepal tips shorter than or about equal to the length of the tube, narrow (0.8 - 4 mm wide), with pointy tips and hairy margins.
part_Text5: five, lobes at the tips usually incurved, alternating with evidently jagged or two-toothed, fused membranes (plaits) about the same length as the petals. The actual petals seldom exceed the interconnected plaits by more than 2 mm.
part_Text7: a two-valved, elliptic capsule with numerous flattened, winged, smooth seeds.
simSp_comments: Gentiana saponaria has often been confused with a more southeastern species, G. catesbaei, but it has brighter green, wider leaves, which are widest near the base, not the middle. Also in G. catesbaei, the sepal tips are longer than the tube and the petal lobes are usually 2 - 4 mm longer than the alternating plaits. Gentiana saponaria is also often confused with a hybrid, G. x billingtonii, which is a cross between G. puberulenta and G. andrewsii. The hybrid however, tends to have leaves and sepal tips that are widest near the base where as in G. saponaria, they are widest near the middle. Also, the leaves of the hybrid tend to be stiffer and lighter green in color than the dark green leaves of G. saponaria. Finally, the flowers of the hybrid appear to be a deeper color blue. The species and two subspecies of G. andrewsii may also be confused with G. saponaria, but their leaves are much wider and possess long pointy tips. Also, unlike G. saponaria the sepal tips of G. andrewsii are much shorter than the connected tube portion.
habitatEcology: Sandy moist prairies and Black Oak savannas, moist or seasonally wet thickets, open woods, or even along railroad tracks, but overall rare in our area.
notes_comments: This species is now extirpated (extinct) in Michigan.  The species has a relatively wide distribution in the United States and a lot of physical variation occurs between different populations as well as within single populations (Pringle 1967).
etymology_comments: Gentiana is named after Gentius, king of Illyria, who supposedly discovered a medicinal value for the yellow gentian. Saponaria refers to the resemblance of the leaves to the common soapwort, which is in the genus Saponaria.
references_citation1: Pringle, J. S. 1967. Taxonomy of Gentiana, section Pneumonanthae, in eastern North America. Brittonia. 19:1-32.

part_Text1: stout, erect, usually with some hairs, especially near the branching inflorescence.
part_Text2: opposite or in whorls of three, stalkless, non-toothed, more than 5 cm long, somewhat lance-shaped, widest below the middle, gradually tapering to a pointy tip, and sometimes with a clasping base.
part_Text3: a terminal, 10 - 40 cm tall,  elongate, "spike" or wand-like cluster with numerous, crowded flowers in the axils of two pointy-tipped, hairy bracts.  There are usually at least two, normally more, flowers per bract axil.
part_Text4: bright purple-red, stalkless, radially symmetric (regular), with sepals and petals fused together most of the sepal length into a slender, eight- to twelve-nerved, hairy sepal-petal tube (hypanthium).
part_Text5: five to seven but fused most of their length with each other and the petals into a long, slender tube (hypanthium), with the separate sepal lobes short-triangular and alternating with much longer (around two times), very thin appendages.
part_Text6: five to seven, fused less than half their length, with separate, ascending or slightly spreading, 0.7 - 1.2 cm long, somewhat oblong or elliptic lobes.
part_Text7: usually twelve (always more than ten ), of different, alternating lengths with half short and half tall.
part_Text8: with a single, superior, two-chambered ovary, a single, slender style, and rounded stigma.  The style of each flower can be one of three possible lengths, short, medium, or tall, in relation to the stamens.
part_Text9: a two-chambered capsule enclosed by the sepal-petal tube (hypanthium), and breaking apart through the side walls of the chambers, not directly into the chambers (septicidal).
simSp_comments: Lythrum salicaria is very similar to another Eurasian species, L. virgatum, which is often cultivated (and escapes), but the plant is not hairy where as L. salicaria is normally hairy, especially in the flowering "spikes". The other species in our area, L. alatum, is native and differs by usually being less than 0.8 m tall, hairless, having a four-angled stem, alternate leaves less than 5 cm long, and always less than ten stamens per flower.
habitatEcology: Native to Eurasia, found in wet places of all kinds and increasingly abundant since it is an invasive plant.
notes_comments: Listed as one of the top 100 of the "World's Worst" invaders (see link below), this plant is native to Eurasia and has escaped cultivation to become an aggressive weed in our natural wetlands and even roadside ditches.  Large patches of this species are seen throughout the Chicago Region.  Though seemingly "pretty" due to the bright purple-red flowers, this plant spreads quickly and chokes out high-quality native wetland plant species, which consequently makes the wetlands less useful for wildlife.  These plants persist year after year as well as produce copious amounts of seed.  Due to the threat this plant poses to our nation's wetlands, the USDA has spearheaded efforts to combat this species by releasing natural biological enemies, beetles from Eurasia, which feed on purple loosestrife.
notes_linkText2: National Project for the Biological Control of Purple Loosestrife

Pusilla) for the biological control of purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria). Weed Science 42:134-140. Excerpt on pollination and beetles.
